sentence: Hedge fund’s Q3 trades are now public following the release of 13F forms filed with the SEC.
For investors, this means that now is the time to track the “Smart Money” of hedge fund gurus like Warren Buffett and Carl Icahn.
And with the innovative Nasdaq Smart Portfolio stock screener, you can easily pinpoint top stocks that match your investment criteria.
The screener has a database of over 5,000 stocks as well as multiple filter options.
Here we searched for stocks with both a positive hedge fund signal and a ‘Strong Buy’ best analyst consensus.
Using our big data analytics, we can also track the stock’s overall outlook from the Street.
This gives us a better idea of whether these stocks make compelling investment opportunities.
Bearing that in mind, let’s now take a closer look at these 3 top stocks.
Salesforce.com (CRM) - Cloud computing giant Salesforce is a top hedge fund stock right now.
In the last quarter, hedge funds increased holdings by a net total of 1.6 million shares.
Big-name fund gurus that leapt into the stock include Ray Dalio and Steve Mandel of the $20 billion Lone Pine Capital LLC fund.
In the last quarter he ramped up his CRM holding by 137% to over $585 million.
However, Frank Sands still takes first place with a massive $1.25 billion position.
And hedge funds aren’t alone in their bullish sentiment.
The Street also has a ‘Strong Buy’ analyst consensus rating on CRM with an average price target of $119 (10.8% upside potential).
CRM is “gobbling up the cloud with another strong quarter and outlook” writes top Drexel Hamilton analyst Brian White on November 22.
He boosted his price target from $120 all the way to $129 (20% upside potential) following the company’s very strong Q3 results and guidance.

“In our view, the cloud trend remains in the early stages and we believe Salesforce represents the best vehicle for investors to play the cloud trend as the company moves toward its $20-22 billion revenue milestone” says White.
He recommends buying the stock on any weakness.
For the quarter, CRM beat on all key metrics with 3Q:FY18 revenue of $2.680 billion (up 25% YoY) vs Street consensus of $2.650 billion and EPS of $0.39 (Street was at $0.37).
Applied Materials (AMAT)- Chip gear maker AMAT is ticking all the boxes.
In Q3, hedge funds snapped up 5.9 million more Applied Materials shares.
Zero hedge funds exited the stock and only 5 reduced positions vs 18 who increased holdings.
UK-based fund manager Egerton’s John Armitage upped his position by 23% to $883 million- making this the fund’s third biggest stock after Comcast and Charter Communications.
“Every Year is a Peak Year for Gary’s [CEO Gary Dickerson] AMAT,” comments Credit Suisse’s Farhan Ahmad.
He reiterated his buy rating on AMAT on November 17 with a $72 price target (27% upside potential) following the stock’s strong fiscal fourth quarter results and upbeat guidance.
Ahmad dismisses the idea that AMAT is a “pure cyclical company”.
Instead, he sees Applied Materials as very much a "growth company" with a "solid" history of buybacks.
During the past 12 years, AMAT has managed to reduce its share count by 35% and is planning a further 6% reduction for the next three years.
Overall AMAT boasts an impressive 15 consecutive buy ratings from analysts in the last three months.
And with a $64.53 average price target, analysts are predicting AMAT can climb 11.43% over the next 12 months.
Incyte Corporation (INCY)- Fund managers refuse to give up on oncology pharma Incyte.

Prices for INCY plunged from $138 in August to the current share price of just under $100 after Gilead Sciences (GILD) snapped up cancer therapy developer Kite Pharma for $11.9 billion instead of Incyte.
But if we turn to TipRanks, the hedge fund confidence signal for Q3 is still ‘very positive’ based on 18 hedge fund transactions.
In terms of the number of shares held by the Smart Money, hedge funds increased holdings in the quarter by a net total of 1.2 million shares.
Renown fund managers like Arthur Cohen, Andrew Law and Joel Greenblatt all initiated new positions in the stock.
For example, Arthur Cohen’s health-focused fund now has a $70 million stake in INCY.
Meanwhile, even with a 5% trim, Frank Sands remains the stock’s biggest shareholder with a huge $883 million position.
INCY has also clung on to its ‘Strong Buy’ analyst consensus rating.
In the last three months, the stock has received six buy ratings versus just 1 hold rating from top analysts.
The icing on the cake: with share prices now at $98, analysts are predicting big upside for INCY of over 54%.

“With one of the deepest/broadest immune-oncology pipelines in the sector, the added flexibility of an in-house PD-1 inhibitor and a potentially first in class oncology asset with an important value inflecting catalyst in the first half of 2018, we think that INCY represents an attractive opportunity with strategic value,” commented JP Morgan analyst Cory Kasimov at the end of October.
His bullish sentiment is reflected in his buy rating and $149 price target.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
